Key Arguments: The Bill threatens democratic rights by allowing the government to define truth and enforce it.
It grants excessive power to ACMA to determine misinformation and disinformation, which is subjective and open to abuse.
The Bill could lead to government censorship through tech companies, stifling free speech.
It promotes ideological conformity and suppresses dissenting voices, contrary to democratic principles.
The Bill lacks transparency and accountability, giving too much power to unelected bureaucrats.
The definition of 'harm' is vague and could be used to shut down legitimate speech.
The Bill does not hold digital service providers accountable for excessive policing of speech.
Excluding government content from the Bill's provisions is hypocritical and creates an asymmetry.
The penalties for non-compliance are excessive and could chill free speech.
The Bill does not meet international standards for protecting freedom of expression.
Notable Quotes: The proposed Combating Misinformation and Disinformation Bill threatens the very essence of our democratic rights.
The Bill effectively enables tech companies to become tools of government censorship, stifling free speech.
The Bill paves the way for ideological conformity, suppressing dissenting voices and hindering independent thought.
The Bill puts too much power in the hands of unelected bureaucrats to silence speech in the public square without transparency or accountability.
